description.narrative:
Svenska ambassaden har beslutat bidra till Europeiska Unionens Trust Fund för postkonflikt i Colombia (European Union Trust Fund for post-conflict in Colombia, EUTF).
Insatsensyftar till att stödja genomförandet av fredsavtalet mellan Colombias regering och FARC. Detta stöd ska hjälpa den colombianska befolkningen att hantera de negativa effekterna av en mer än 50 år gammal intern väpnad konflikt.
De frågor denna fond kommer hantera är som följer: landsbygdsutveckling med en territoriellinriktning, stimulering av ekonomisk aktivitet och produktivitet i avlägsna landsändar märkta av konflikten, landinnehav, hållbar utveckling, kvinnligt entreprenörskap, återhämtningsförmåga, statlig närvaro och tillhandahållande av samhällstjänsteroch infrastruktur.

The Embassy of Sweden in Colombia has decided to be part of the four post-conflict funds framed upon the government’s strategy “Colombia in Peace”. The European Union Trust Fund is one of these four funds and it aims to tackle one of the main roots of conflict: inequality and poverty in remote rural areas affected by conflict.
The overall objective of the Trust Fund is to support the implementation of the provisions established in the Peace Agreement between the Government of Colombia and the FARC. The activities, which will focus on the early recovery and stabilization phases of the post-conflict, will be in line with the territorial focus of the peace agreement and with EU priorities and principles, and will build on the experience achieved in this area by the EU and its Member States.
The general objectives of the Trust Fund, with the main focus on sustainable rural development at the local level, will be, inter alia, to seek to support programmes on government reform, decentralisation and citizen participation and to aim to strengthen involvement by civil society, and to strengthen the general resilience notably of the population groups in most vulnerable conditions such as women, victims, indigenous peoples, and afro-descendants.
The European Commission in Colombia acts as the manager of the Trust Fund and is responsible for the implementation of the actions and reporting of the activities financed by the Trust Fund. The Commission is entrusted with the responsibility of managing the Embassy’s contribution in accordance with the procedures applicable to the expenditure of the EU, in this sense; the European Commission is designated to deal with the day to day technical and financial management and administration of the Fund, which also includes coordination of the different implementing partners.
The EUTF’s governance structure has been designed in a way that facilitates the follow-up on the implementation and oversight of the Fund’s activities as well as to review progress and provide strategic overall guidance of the Fund (Strategic Board and Operational Committee). The Commission receives and administers the contributions from the donors and disburses the funds to the implementing partners. The implementing partners, the objectives of each project and the indicative budget (among others) are to be approved by the Trust Fund’s Operational Committee where Sweden plays an important role.

To support the implementation of the provisions established in the Peace Agreement between the Government of Colombia and the FARC and to accompany the Colombian population in overcoming the negative effects of the 50-year old internal armed conflict; specifically regarding the firts point of the agreement related to integral rural development.

tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.

1.5 - By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.

1.5 - Till 2030 bygga upp motståndskraften hos de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer och minska deras utsatthet och sårbarhet för extrema klimatrelaterade händelser och andra ekonomiska, sociala och miljömässiga chocker och katastrofer.
16.b - Promote and enforce non-discriminatory laws and policies for sustainable development.
16.b - Verka för och genomdriva icke-diskriminerande lagstiftning och politik för en hållbar utveckling.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.

9.1 - Bygga ut tillförlitlig, hållbar och motståndskraftig infrastruktur av hög kvalitet, inklusive regional och gränsöverskridande infrastruktur, för att stödja ekonomisk utveckling och människors välbefinnande, med fokus på ekonomiskt överkomlig och rättvis tillgång för alla.

9.1 - Develop quality, reliable, sustainable and resilient infrastructure, including regional and transborder infrastructure, to support economic development and human well-being, with a focus on affordable and equitable access for all.

description.narrative: By the end of 2018, 16 projects were on-going representing a Trust Fund contribution of € 56.5 million. Further 5 projects worth € 13 million had been adopted by the Operational Committee and were in the contracting process. Out of those 16 projects, 2 started its implementation in 2017, 10 during the first semester of 2018 and 4 during the second semester. Therefore, the peak of the Trust Fund implementation is expected to take place during 2019. Out of the 16 projects that are under implementation, 11 of them address the first strategic priority of the Trust Fund, fostering economic development in conflict affected territories and reinforcing State presence. Save for the first project, “Strengthening of integrated interventions mechanisms in marginalized rural areas of Colombia” (located in Chocó, Cauca, Valle del Cauca and Meta), adopted in January 2017 before the geographic priorities of the Fund were established, all of these projects take place in the Departments of Nariño, Caquetá, Guaviare and Putumayo. With regards to the second priority of the Fund, support to the reincorporation of former combatants, one project is currently ongoing (FAO) and two other have been approved by the Operational Committee and should start in early 2019 (ECOMUN and Humanicemos). Still in the area of reincorporation, the EU Trust Fund completed during 2018 the Call for Proposals from Civil Society on reincorporation. 3 contracts were awarded and should start in early 2019. The Trust Fund projects have also been able to provide quick wins for beneficiaries, be it in terms productive infrastructure (7 fish farming facilities, poultry and pork processing infrastructure, pineapple processing facility for ex-combatants), training (e.g. 61 women certified in rural journalism and peace-building, scholarships awarded to rural youth) or increased access to market (projects have started to export coffee to Europe and Australia, bananas to USA, peasant markets –mercados campesinos- have been established or revamped, food security activities have begun to yield results) 30% of the projects monitored during 2018 presented delays in their implementation and report difficulties on implementation. Most of these difficulties are linked to the security situation in the field. An intense monitoring activity will be necessary in 2019 to ensure that action can be taken where needed and projects are kept on track. Most of the projects have started in 2018 and therefore are still at a very initial phase to produce tangible results. However, most report that levels of trust on the peace process have increased in the areas where we are present, projects have managed in many cases to offer some hope to populations that have historically been badly hit by the conflict.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
